contentrichtext.text: {{refimprove|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox Museum |name = Coventry Transport Museum |image = Coventry Transport Museum (1).jpg |imagesize = 250 |map_type = |map_caption = |latitude = 52.4108 |longitude = -1.5092 |established = |dissolved = |location = [[Coventry]], England |type = Transport Museum |visitors = |director = |director = Gary Hall |curator = Steve Bagley |publictransit = Coventry Railway Station (London Euston to Birmingham line) 15 minutes walk or buses numbered 17, 27, 49 stop near the Museum. |website = {{URL|http://www.transport-museum.com}} }} [[File:Coventry Time Zone Clock.jpg|thumb|The control panel of the ''Time Zone Clock'' in front of Coventry Transport Museum.]] The '''Coventry Transport Museum''' (formerly known as the ''Museum of British Road Transport'') is a motor [[museum]], located in [[Coventry]] City Centre, England. It houses a collection of British-made [[road transport]]. It is located in Coventry because the city was previously the centre of the British car industry. There are more than 240 [[Automobile|cars]] and commercial vehicles, 100 [[motorcycle]]s, 200 [[bicycle]]s. Admission to the museum is free. It has a full-time archive department, which deals with an array of historical items, and offers a public enquiry service answering questions and finding items and information. == Exhibits == Notable exhibits in the museum are [[Thrust2]] and [[ThrustSSC]], the British jet cars which broke the [[land speed record]] in 1983 and 1997 respectively and some of the Royal cars - Queen Mary's and King George V's State limousines. Many "conventional" cars are in the collection, including an [[Austin Allegro]], an [[Austin Metro]] previously owned by Lady Diana Spencer, a [[Ford Escort (Europe)|Ford Escort MK2]], [[Hillman Imp]], [[Triumph Acclaim]], [[Chrysler Sunbeam|Talbot Sunbeam]], [[Chrysler Horizon|Talbot Horizon]], [[Peugeot 206]], [[Peugeot 405]] and a [[DeLorean DMC-12]] car made famous by the ''Back to The Future'' films. A Humber staff car used by [[Bernard Montgomery, 1st Viscount Montgomery of Alamein|General Montgomery]] during the Second World War is also on display. The museum displays many [[Jaguar Cars|Jaguars]] and other Coventry built cars such as the [[Triumph Motor Company|Triumph]], [[Humber (car)|Humber]] and [[Standard Motor Company|Standard]] marques, an [[Alvis Car and Engineering Company Ltd|Alvis]] tank, [[Massey Ferguson]] tractors, and Coventry built buses, including the bus that the Coventry City football team paraded in after their victory in the [[1987 FA Cup Final]]. Coventry motorcycle marques are also represented in the museum's collection including: [[Triumph Engineering|Triumph]], [[Francis-Barnett]], [[Rudge-Whitworth]], and [[Coventry-Eagle]] and it is affiliated to the [[British Motorcycle Charitable Trust]].<ref name="BMCT">{{cite web|url=http://www.bmct.org/index.html|title=British Motorcycle Charitable Trust|accessdate=29 November 2009}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Coventry Transport Museum}} *{{Official website|http://www.transport-museum.com}} *[http://wiki.transport-museum.com The museum's Wiki] *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/coventry/webcams/stories/2004/new-transport-museum-tour.shtml Museum virtual tour] (BBC) [[Category:Museums in Coventry]] [[Category:Automobile museums in England]] [[Category:Transport museums in England]] [[Category:Motorcycle museums in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Coventry Transport Museum]] [[Category:Museums with wikis]]
